title: "being a squishy damage dealer, not a tanky disruptor." ~riot's view on ekko
body: place your bets on riot still fucking up with ekko.

replies.body: being an assassin with delayed damage and high utility was doomed to fail horribly

Yet thats what they want to turn all the assassins into (the delayed part). They love zed ~~because lcs plays~~ because he has counterplay in his delayed ult. They said they want Kat to Shunpo more but her abilities to kill slower. LB is going to rely on more trickery and stay in the fight longer. Hell, they straight out said in the beginning of the assassin rework announcement that they wanted to add more counterplay and one big way was slowing down their TTK. 

So i really hope their goal of "finding them a fall back" actually works out. Otherwise i see a whole mess of tank Fiora type builds coming out where they just rely on their bases. Because none of these have utility like Ekko to utilize

Well its also been said that their TTK's won't be increasing THAT much, maybe by half a second for some of them. Only time will tell how things will work out to be honest.

Ekko (due to how delayed his kit is) has to stay in a fight for several seconds even when built full damage, simply because every skill he has, has a delay on it, sans E.

In league's case the best way of increasing TTK for assassins is not to make the burst take longer to come out, but to make it easier for you to know its coming up, as much as I hate Zed, his ultimate is the perfect example of it, on top of the time it takes for the mark to pop, you also have that small window of time where Zed is not in game anymore because of the animation for his ultimate, you're not tanking damage but you know its coming, and that half second is the best way to give the enemy more reaction time instead of just making the burst take longer to tick.

The only thing I hate about Zed's ult is that there is usually very little you can do against it despite the delay. 

Yes there's ways to play around it, but those usually require the reflexes or game knowledge of high elo. In low elo it's pretty much a guaranteed kill for anyone without hourglass. 

There's counterplay but it doesn't feel clear.
That's because of the rest of his kit, most of the time after he ults you're dodging up to 6 skills at the same time and that can feel a little overwhelming.

Exactly. I can see how pro players can do it, but as a regular it seems a little insane. 

It kinda annoys me that I have to play harder than I normally do just to be on even terms with champions like Yasuo or Zed. I know I can win, it's just...well it gets my blood pumping.

Take exaughst into him. It seems odd on a mid but I have done it a few times and it works great. 
As soon as he ults, just exaughst or CC him in some way, any little bit of disruption goes a long way to mitigate the damage.
Exaughst isn't purely defensive either it makes for a good way to secure kills as well.

The frustration is that he usually returns to his shadow so quickly that I can't target him. 

Again I understand the counterplay. I just don't like facing him.

Zed has a 1 second lockout from bouncing back to his shadow. In addition, he always shows up behind your character model. Using this, you can pinpoint exactly where he is going to be and you have an entire second to execute the exhaust. If he's the only champ around, you can spam the spell button and hope your button spam occurs before he can use a lot of his abilities (lol)
that 1 second lockout only applies to ult shadow. if he laid down a w shadow before hand, he can swap to it instantly after he reappears.

because in the time it takes for a zed to do 1  2-skill combo, the death is basically already guaranteed on a  squishy target. You need the proper comp to specifically peel Zed off of you in perfect timing, and that can be hard to do with high ping.  Riot also REMOVED counterplay by changing QSS.

Zhonya is working just fine, taking exhaust also helps a lot. Even if he shadows away and you get exhaust off it helps a lot with mitigating quite a bit of damage. The only time I see Zed's dominate is in low elo and even that stops happening when you get in gold (it seems that the majority of silver/bronze want to believe he's a God-tier champ).

The problem is if you don't specifically reserve those summoner spells/skills/ + babysit your ADC, you can easily get cheesed,on even a low-income zed. Can I reliebaly peel a Zed off a squishy? Yes, I can--but it takes a lot at times. Also, the removal of QSS is still kind of hypocritical to their supoosed emphasis on counterplay.

Your reply made it sound like it was from a support's pov, so with that in mind:

Depending on pick order and how your team picks against a Zed it's really not that hard to pick a support that can lock down Zed ( {{champion:89}} {{champion:25}}{{champion:223}} ). If you're bot lane you should have a ward in river whenever you want to push the lane so you can be aware of Zed roaming. Tahm's a great choice as devour makes it so if you swallow someone before Zed actually hits the champ to apply the mark in his ult it doesn't do any damage.

I get that you have to be aware of the CD of skills, summoners, etc. but Zed has CD as well; if he can't kill you in one full rotation your odds of surviving are pretty high if you didn't overextend to begin with. Your team actually should think about the picks they make if it's that serious of an issue or just outright ban him. If they don't then that's a failing as a team. 

Lissandra and Swain do an insanely good job against Zed as well as Vlad, Kennen, Lulu so that pretty much covers top and mid picks. 

Map awareness is pretty OP against a roaming Zed.

I love the concept though, total kill time has always been a problem when a low total kill time's purpose is to stop DPS, but the fact assassins were fundamentally based around two strengths:

1. Their TTK is inherently shorter than the casting time of mages and supports in some cases, therefore making their effective DPS literally 0 regardless of how fed they are. Or just build tank and ignore the DPS.

2. Mobility

always annoyed the hell out of me. 

Now Riot's dealing with this whole new challenge never before seen in LoL balance: How does riot make a defensive ability that doesn't benefit tankiness?

Some of their answers include tankiness regardless of tankiness (fizz pole always negates all damage in a short amount of time, LeBlanc's jukes always reduce the damage of a skill shot to 0) but since even ADCs with 0 defensiveness can be built bruiser it didn't work well as the champion had to actively discourage tankiness (a bit like soraka except less extreme).

I'm guessing Riot will make the defensive ability of an assassin require more active thinking to discourage building tank and spamming defensive abilities mindlessly, then maybe make their defensive abilities have windows of time where they can't do anything to contribute compared to a tank who can pop a shield and still dish out damage and cc? Like a forced version of waiting in the backline for cooldowns before going in the burst another target.

Ekko was so balanced as full AP at first though, he wasn't even weak on release, he was so healthy. I'm sad he had to be ruined because of tank builds.

release ekko tank build was strong since it was the same shit, but ekko was more played AP because it was more broken on release.

Tbh, most people only use the "w" for the stun/shield anyway. I guess the slow is redundant compensation for being unable to activate the stun.

After the removal of those I really cant see people complaining about Ekko much anymore.

~200k mastery ekko

The only way you can incentivize proper squishy assasin builds is to remove his cc, all of it, but leave him with self-buffs that he can still use.

Aww come on - how can you not see how well he was designed before he was even released? Riot was just trying to make reliable assassins, and Ekko was a move in the right direction.  Sometimes assassins have difficulties sticking to targets, so they gave him 3 slows, an AoE stun, a speed up, and a dash / blink combo to help with that.  But sometimes assassins get bursted down too quickly, so they gave him a shield, and an oops button that teleports him back to a location, heals him, and does an AoE nuke around the area just to boost his damage a bit.  Plus, assassins fall behind if they don't get kills, so the 3 hit passive procs and the percent health execute damage passive on his W will allow him to still do damage to beefy targets without needing to have a lot of AP.

With his kit being the way it currently is, he's basically incentivized into building somewhat tanky, even if he didn't have all of the utility he does. the fact that his burst takes time (and unlike Zed, he's forced to remain near his target for more than a few seconds), means that if he wasn't tanky, he'd be very likely to just be blown up before his target dies.

Edit: To be honest, I can't even think of a way to make AP ekko the more desirable choice, outside of just making his kit faster (as in, giving his opponents less time to react then they currently have)

One could make the argument that his W's hard CC allows him to make interesting plays to work around his aforementioned weakness, which is true but W is somewhat unreliable. Basically, no matter what kind of changes you make, as long as Ekko is forced to stay near his target for an extended period of time, building tanky will always be the better choice.

Yep, pretty sure they will fuck up. The idea of an squishy **delayed** damage dealer that is **melee** simply can't work in the current league.
